media_caption: Isabelo de los Reyes Sr, ca 1937
text_description: Amidst all the attacks and criticisms on the komedya from the sarsuwela camp, Isabelo de los Reyes (in photo) defends the genre in his “Ang Comediang Tagalog,” arguing that the form is Filipino, and that knowledgeable theater artists should work with komedya artists to develop the full potentials of the art. (Photo from wikimediacommmons/Jackievon)

media_caption: Sining Kambayoka Ensemble’s Mga Kuwentong Maranao, Dulaang Rajah Sulayman, Manila, 1974
text_description: One of the first plays to emerge from Mindanao, Mga Kuwentong Maranao, a play which incorporated 13 Maranao folktales, written by Frank G. Rivera, is staged by Sining Kambayoka Ensemble at the Dulaang Raha Sulayman, Fort Santiago, Manila. (PETA Library and Archives)

media_caption: Pasyon reading in Cavite, 2009
text_description: The chanting of the pasyon must have started soon after publication of the first pasyon. Photo: Pasyon reading in Cavite, 2009 (Marc Dalma)

media_caption: A 1948 staging of Wanted: A Chaperone
text_description: One of Wilfrido Ma. Guerrero’s notable works, Wanted: A Chaperone, is first staged by The Filipino Players at the St. Cecilia’s Hall of St. Scholastica’s College in Manila. Photo: A 1948 staging of Wanted: A Chaperone (Photo from Nicanor G. Tiongson)

media_caption: Lou Veloso and Joy Soler-de Castro in Tanghalang Pilipino’s Bayan-bayanan, 1989
text_description: Bayan-bayanan, an early play on Filipino immigrants, written by Bienvenido M. Noriega Jr is first staged by Teatro Pilipino at the CCP. (Photo from Tanghalang Pilipino)

media_caption: Kamanyang Dramatic Troupe performing a street play, Tutuban Station, 1971
text_description: During and after the First Quarter Storm of 1970, artists involved in the national democratic cultural revolution against the “culture of the status quo” stage such plays as the Kamanyang Players’ Pakikibaka and Ang Kalbaryo ni Juan de la Cruz; Gintong Silahis’ Barikada and Tanging Paraan, and Panday Sining ’s Tunggalian. (Photo from Nicanor G. Tiongson)

media_caption: PETA's Ang Paglilitis ni Mang Serapio, 1971
article_title: Theater 1969 Ang Paglilitis ni Mang Serapio
text_description: Ang Paglilitis ni Mang Serapio, the seminal work of Paul Dumol which won the Dulaang Sibol’s Paligsahang Pandulaan in 1967, is first staged at the Ateneo High School. Photo: PETA's Ang Paglilitis ni Mang Serapio, 1971 (PETA Library and Archives)

media_caption: Vic Silayan and Lily Gamboa, center, with Lolita Rodriguez and Nick Lizaso, in PETA’s Bayaning Huwad, Dulaang Rajah Sulayman, Manila, 1967
media_credit: Photo from Romy Vitug, National Library of the Philippines Collection
text_description: The Philippine Educational Theater Association (PETA) is inaugurated with a staging of Bayaning Huwad by Virginia Moreno, under the direction of the organization’s founder, Cecile Guidote. (Photo by Romy Vitug, National Library of the Philippines Collection)

media_caption: PETA’s Panata sa Kalayaan, 1986
text_description: PETA’s Panata sa Kalayaan, the organization's ode and pledge to freedom after the EDSA Revolt, is staged in CCP and later tours abroad. (Photo from CCP)

media_caption: Komedya Don Galo's Prinsipe Rodante, Parañaque City, 2008
text_description: Prinsipe Rodante is the inaugural play for the founding year of Komedya ng Don Galo. The organizers decide to transform komedya arts to teen theater aesthetics. Photo: Komedya ng Don Galo's Prinsipe Rodante, Parañaque City, 2008 (Nikki Seranilla Briones)

media_caption: Mobile Theater Foundation's Martir sa Golgota, CCP, 2013
text_description: Martir sa Golgota, a sinakulo produced by Tanghalang Santa Ana under the direction of Lou Veloso, is first presented to the people of Santa Ana. Photo: Mobile Theater Foundation's Martir sa Golgota, CCP, 2013 (CCP Collection)

media_caption: Gantimpala Theater, one of the Philstage member companies, performing Kanser, The Musicale, 2011
text_description: The Philippine Legitimate Stage Artists Group Inc (Philstage) is established. It institutes the annual Gawad Buhay! to honor productions of its member companies. Photo: Gantimpala Theater, one of the Philstage member companies, performing Kanser, The Musicale, 2011 (Gantimpala Theater Foundation)

media_caption: Si Handyong at si Baltog from Anino Shadowplay Collective's full-length play Ibalon, 2000
text_description: Anino Shadowplay Collective’s first full-length play, Ibalon, based on the Bikol creation myth, is staged at the UP Diliman College of Music. (Photo from Anino Shadowplay Collective)

media_caption: A performance of Papet Pasyon by Teatrong Mulat ng Pilipinas, 2017
text_description: Papet Pasyon, the annual puppet play on the passion of Christ by Amelia Lapeña-Bonifacio, is first performed at the CCP. Photo: Papet Pasyon, 2017 (Photo by Vladimeir B. Gonzales)

media_caption: Dulaang UP's 2017 staging of Bagong Cristo
text_description: Bagong Cristo, one of the early attempts to reinterpret the Christ story according to labor conditions, is penned by Aurelio V. Tolentino. Photo: Dulaang UP's 2017 staging of Bagong Cristo (Adrian Begonia)

media_caption: The courtship scene in Tanikalang Guinto, 1902
text_description: Tanikalang Guinto, a drama simboliko by Juan Abad, is first staged at the Teatro Libertad. The play’s performance in Batangas, Batangas on May 10, 1903 is closed down, and Abad is sentenced to imprisonment for two years and fined $2,000, by an American judge. (Photo from Nicanor G. Tiongson)

media_caption: Lou Veloso in Taong Grasa, 2014
text_description: Lou Veloso plays the title role in the Dulaang UP’s production of Taong Grasa by Anton Juan Jr. Photo: Lou Veloso in Taong Grasa, 2014 (Anton Juan Jr)

media_caption: Ditchay Roxas as the Socialite in PETA’s Buwan at Baril in E-flat Major, Dulaang Rajah Sulayman, Manila, 1985
text_description: PETA’s Buwan at Baril sa E-flat major, written by Chris Millado and directed by Apolonio B. Chua, merges artistic and political concerns in representations of a society gripped by authoritarianism and the forces that fight against it. (Photo from PETA Library and Archives)

media_caption: A performance of loa in Taal, Batangas, 1990
text_description: Fr. Joaquin Martinez de Zuñiga witnesses a komedya performance in San Jose, Batangas and notes the inclusion of lua/loa in the performance. Photo: A performance of loa in Taal, Batangas, 1990 (CCP Collection)

media_caption: Portrait of Praxedes Julia Fernandez aka Yeyeng, star of the Spanish zarzuela in the 1890s
text_description: The performances of Pascual Bailon and the cancan of Praxedes Julia “Yeyeng” Fernandez (in photo) at the Teatro de Variedades draw a pastoral letter from Archbishop P. Payo against “indecorous public performances.” (Photo from La Ilustracion Filipina)

media_caption: The cakewalk scene, Filipinas para los Filipinos, Manila, 1905
text_description: Filipinas para los Filipinos of Severino Reyes, critical of America’s racist policy, is performed (Photo from Excelsior, 31 Dec 1905)

media_caption: Komedya Don Galo's Prinsipe Rodante, Parañaque City, 2008
text_description: Max Allanigue completes Prinsipe Rodante, a landmark reworking of komedya dramaturgy, which revolutionizes and modernizes the genre. It sparks a battle between the traditional elders and the young “turks” in San Dionisio, Parañaque. Photo: Komedya Don Galo's Prinsipe Rodante, Parañaque City, 2008 (Photo from Nikki Seranilla Briones)

article_title: Theater 1987 National Artist Atang de la Rama
text_description: Atang de la Rama is proclaimed National Artist for Theater and Music.

media_caption: National Artist for Theater and Film Lamberto Avellana
text_description: Lamberto V. Avellana is proclaimed National Artist for theater and film. (Photo from CCP)

media_caption: National Artist for Theater Daisy Hontiveros-Avellana. awarded in 1999
text_description: Daisy Hontiveros-Avellana is conferred the National Artist Award for Theater. (Photo from CCP)

media_caption: Gawad CCP para sa Sining awardee Daisy Hontiveros-Avellana
text_description: Gawad CCP para sa Sining is awarded to Daisy Hontiveros Avellana for Theater. (Photo from CCP)

media_caption: National Artist for Theater Design Salvador Bernal awarded in 2003
text_description: Salvador F. Bernal becomes the first National Artist for Theater Design. (Photo from Philippine Daily Inquirer)

media_caption: National Artist for Theater Severino Montano, awarded in 2001
text_description: Severino Montano is conferred the National Artist award for Theater. (Photo from CCP)

media_caption: Cynthia Culig-Guico in PETA's Palasyo ni Valentin, 2005
text_description: The PETA Theater Center in Quezon City is inaugurated with Mario O’Hara’s Palasyo ni Valentin, under the direction of Soxie Topacio. Photo: Cynthia Culig-Guico in PETA's Palasyo ni Valentin, 2005 (PETA Library and Archives)

media_caption: Compañia de Zarzuela Ilagan with founder-director Hermogenes Ilagan, seated at the center, early 1900s
text_description: Dalagang Bukid, a very popular Tagalog sarsuwela by Hermogenes Ilagan, with music by Leon Ignacio, is first staged by the Compañia de Zarzuela Ilagan (in photo) at the Teatro Zorrilla, Manila with Atang de la Rama as lead. (Photo from UP Library)

media_caption: Teatro Pabrika performance in a workers’ strike, ca 1980
text_description: With Kabuhayang Tagpi-tagpi, a skit on workers’ oppression and resistance, Teatro Pabrika shifts from grim and determined discourse to light and effective communication, with the use of bodabil techniques, salin-awit (use of pop melodies on new relevant lyrics), audience participation, and puns on television commercials. It is mounted generally for workers mass actions. (Photo from CCP)

media_caption: Dulaang UP’s …And St. Louis Loves Dem Filipinos, UP Diliman, 1992
article_title: Theater 1992 And St. Louis Loves Dem Filipinos
text_description: The historical play …And St. Louis Loves Dem Filipinos by Floy Quintos, is first staged, under the direction of Tony Mabesa, by Dulaang UP in UP Diliman. (Photo by Nilo Odiaman, Dulaang UP)

media_caption: Dulaang UP’s Abadeja: Ang Ating Sinderela, 1977
text_description: Abadeja: Ang Ating Sinderela by Amelia Lapeña Bonifacio is staged by Teatro Mulat, formed in 1973 but renamed as Teatrong Mulat ng Pilipinas in 1978. (Photo from Amelia Lapeña-Bonifacio)

media_caption: 1975 staging of Alang Dios!
media_credit: Photo from Lino Sanchez and Carmen Cochon
text_description: A Kapampangan sarsuwela, Alang Dios!, by Juan Crisostomo Soto, with music by Pablo Palma, is first staged at Teatro Sabina in Bacolor, Pampanga. Photo: 1975 staging of Alang Dios! (Lino Sanchez and Carmen Cochon)

article_title: Theater 1975 Palanca full-length category first winners
text_description: The first winners of the Don Carlos Palanca Memorial Awards for Literature for the full-length play category are Nonilon Queaño, Bienvenido M. Noriega Jr, and Azucena Grajo Uranza, in the Filipino division; and Nick Joaquin, Manuel M. Martell, and by Elsa M. Coscolluela, in the English division.
The Writers Bloc’s annual festival of “untried, unstaged, untested” plays dubbed as the Virgin Labfest starts with eight plays at the CCP.

media_caption: ENTABLADO’s staging of Chris Martinez's one-act play Baclofen, Ateneo de Manila University, 2008
text_description: ENternteyment para sa Tao, Bayan, LAnsangan at DiyOs (ENTABLADO) is established in Ateneo de Manila University as a response to the social ferment of the period and champions original works in Filipino. Photo: ENTABLADO’s staging of Chris Martinez's one-act play Baclofen, Ateneo de Manila University, 2008 (Ateneo ENTABLADO)

media_caption: Bulwagang Gantimpala’s Bombita, CCP, Manila, 1981
text_description: Bombita (in photo) by Tony Perez, a play on the absurdity of subservience, is first staged by the Bulwagang Gantimpala at the Bulwagang Gantimpala of the CCP. It is the first in a trilogy of the author’s journey plays, which includes Biyaheng Timog, 1984, and Sa North Diversion Road, 1988. (Photo from CCP)

media_caption: UP Repertory and Dulaang UP’s Ang Bundok, UP Diliman, 1976
text_description: Ang Bundok, the contemporary sarsuwela by Amelia Lapeña- Bonifacio, inaugurates the renovated and renamed Wilfrido Ma. Guerrero Theater, formerly the College of Arts and Sciences Little Theater, UP Diliman. (Photo from CCP)

media_caption: PETA’s Damas de Noche, Dulaang Rajah Sulayman, Manila, 1991
text_description: Damas de Noche (in photo) by Joi Barrios, under the direction of Brenda Fajardo, and Rody Vera’s Kung Paano Ko Pinatay si Diana Ross, under Soxy Topacio, are first presented in a twinbill entitled Baligtaran: Dalawang Dula Ukol sa Kasarian by PETA at Dulaang Rajah Sulayman, Fort Santiago, Manila. (PETA Library and Archives)

media_caption: Rayna Reyes, left, Jonathan Tadioan, and Sherry Lara in Tanghalang Pilipino’s Doc Resureccion: Gagamutin ang Bayan, CCP, Manila, 2012
text_description: Doc Resureccion: Gagamutin ang Bayan, breakthrough play of Layeta Bucoy, is first staged under the direction of Tuxqs Rutaquio, as part of the Virgin Labfest 5 at the CCP. (Photo from Tanghalang Pilipino)

media_caption: Frances Makil-Ignacio, at the back, and Jonathan Tadioan and Ana Abad Santos, in front, in Evening at the Opera, Virgin Labfest, CCP, 2011
text_description: Evening at the Opera by Floy Quintos is first staged, under Jomari Jose, as part of the Virgin Labfest 7. (Photo from Virgie Sorita)

media_caption: Half an Hour in a Convent, Manila Grand Opera House, 1941
text_description: Half an Hour in a Convent, by Wilfrido Ma. Guerrero, the first play to tackle the subject of suicide and the repression in Catholic convent schools, is first staged by an acting and directing class of Jean Edades at the UP Little Theater in Padre Faura. Photo: Half an Hour in a Convent, Manila Grand Opera House, 1941 (UP Library)

media_caption: Sining Kambayoka Ensemble’s Halik sa Kampilan, 1987
text_description: Halik sa Kampilan by Frank G. Rivera is first staged by the Sining Kambayoka ensemble as part of the Pistang Kambayoka at the CCP. (Photo from Nicanor G. Tiongson)

media_caption: PETA’s Halimaw, featuring Lito Flores and Angie Ferro, Dulaang Rajah Sulayman, Manila, 1971
text_description: PETA stages Halimaw, a modern sarsuwela written by Isagani R. Cruz, with music by Lutgardo Labad Jr, direction by Nonon Padilla, and starring Lito Flores and Angie Ferro (in photo), at the Dulaang Raha Sulayman, Intramuros, Manila. (Photo from PETA Library and Archives)

media_caption: Manny Castañeda, at the back, and Lino Brocka in PETA’s Hanggang Dito na Lamang at Maraming Salamat, Dulaang Rajah Sulayman, Manila, 1974
text_description: PETA stages Paraisong Parisukat and Hanggang Dito na Lamang at Maraming Salamat, both written by Orlando Nadres, and directed by Lutgardo Labad Jr, at the Dulaang Dambana in Fort Santiago, Manila. Hanggang Dito na Lamang at Maraming Salamat (in photo) is the first Filipino play to openly tackle homosexuality. (Photo from Nicanor G. Tiongson)

media_caption: 2009 staging of Hiblang Abo
text_description: A seminal work by Rene Villanueva,Hiblang Abo, is first staged under Tony Espejo, by Bulwagang Gantimpala at the CCP. Photo: 2009 staging of Hiblang Abo (Gantimpala Theater Foundation)

media_caption: Dulaang UP’s Hinabing Pakpak ng Ating Mga Anak, UP Diliman, 2008
text_description: A homage to Rene Villanueva and society’s neglected children, Hinabing Pakpak ng Ating mga Anak by Anton Juan Jr, is first staged by Dulaang UP at the UP Diliman. (Photo from Dulaang UP)

media_caption: Ilokula staged by Peryante at the Quirino Grandstand, Rizal Park, Manila, 1984
text_description: Ilokula: Ang Ilokanong Drakula II by Chris Millado is first staged by Peryante at the Palma Hall Steps in UP Diliman. Photo: Ilokula staged by Peryante at the Quirino Grandstand, Rizal Park, Manila, 1984 (Photo from Nicanor G. Tiongson)

media_caption: Staging of In My Father’s House in Silliman University, 2013
media_credit: Photo by Urich Calumpang, Silliman University Culture and Arts Council
text_description: In My Father’s House by Elsa Martinez-Coscolluela is first staged, under the direction of Tony Mabesa, by the UP Playwright’s Theater at the UP Diliman. Photo: Staging of In My Father’s House in Silliman University, 2013 (Photo by Urich Calumpang, Silliman University Culture and Arts Council)

media_caption: Dalubdulaan's staging of Josephine at the Metropolitan Theater, 1980
text_description: Josephine by Isagani Cruz is staged by Dulaang UP; with direction by Tony Mabesa and costume design by Salvador Bernal. Photo: Dalubdulaan's staging of Josephine at the Metropolitan Theater, 1980 (CCP Collection)

media_caption: Aquinas University’s Kantada ni Daragong Magayon, Mandirigma, Legazpi, Albay, 2000
text_description: Cantata of Daragang Magayon, Warrior Woman, an H. Francisco Peñones adaptation of Merlinda Bobis’s epic poem of the same title, is presented by Aquinas University, The Sorsogon CBTG, and Letra, directed by Jazmin B. Llana. (Photo from Kaloi Garcia, Aquinas University)

media_caption: Harlene Bautista, left, Tuxqs Rutaquio, Dyna Padilla, Justeen Niebres, and Charisssa Pascual in UP Theater Council’s Last Order sa Penguin, UP Diliman, 2000
text_description: Last Order sa Penguin by Chris Martinez is first staged by the UP Theater Council at UP Diliman. (Photo from Tuxqs Rutaquio)

media_caption: Nanding Josef and Mia Gutierrez in UP Departamento ng Filipino’s Mayo A-Beinte Uno Atbp. Kabanata, UP Diliman, 1978
text_description: A seminal play on the life of Lapiang Malaya leader Valentin “Tatang” de los Santos, Mayo A-Beinte Uno Atbp. Kabanata, by Al Santos, under the direction of Joel Lamangan is first staged by Samahan ng Mag-aaral sa Pilipino and the Department of Filipino at the UP Diliman. (Photo from CCP)

media_caption: Rustica Carpio and Samuel Fernandez in New Yorker in Tondo, 1983
text_description: Marcelino Agana Jr.’s New Yorker in Tondo, a farce on the Filipinos’ colonial mentality is first staged by the Far Eastern University (FEU) Drama Guild at the FEU Auditorium in Manila. Photo: Rustica Carpio and Samuel Fernandez in New Yorker in Tondo, 1983 (CCP Collection)

media_caption: PETA’s Nukleyar, Dulaang Rajah Sulayman, Manila, 1983
media_credit: Photo by William B. Tan, PETA Library and Archives
text_description: To protest the building of the Bataan Nuclear Power Plant, Nukleyar I by Al Santos is staged, under Manny Pambid and Khryss Adalia’s direction, by PETA at the Fort Santiago, Manila. It is followed by the staging of Nukleyar II in 1985. (Photo by William B. Tan, PETA Library and Archives)

media_caption: Peryante’s Oratoryo ng Bayan, 1984
text_description: Oratoryo ng Bayan, a staging based on the Declaration of Human Rights of the United Nations, by Alan Glinoga, Rody Vera et al, is first staged, under the direction of Apolonio B. Chua by PETA at the Fort Santiago, Manila as part of the MAKIISA People’s Culture Festival. (Photo from CCP)

media_caption: 1911 staging of Ang Paghigugma sa Yutang Natawhan
media_credit: Photo from Turn of the Century, GCF Books, 1980
text_description: Ang Paghigugma sa Yutang Natawhan, Cebuano sarsuwela by Vicente Sotto, is staged at Teatro Junquera. Because of its success, the Compania de Aficionados Filipinos is established, the first organization of theater artists in Cebu. Photo: 1911 staging of Ang Paghigugma sa Yutang Natawhan (Turn of the Century, GCF Books, 1980)

media_caption: 2006 staging of Ang Paglalakbay ni Sisa: Isang Noh sa Laguna
text_description: Ang Paglalakbay ni Sisa: Isang Noh sa Laguna by Amelia Lapeña-Bonifacio, the first Philippine contemporary play to utilize a traditional Japanese genre for Rizal’s Sisa story, is first staged, under the direction of Tony Mabesa at the Abelardo Theater of UP Diliman. Photo: 2006 staging of Ang Paglalakbay ni Sisa: Isang Noh sa Laguna (UPCIS)

Palasyo ni Valentin by Mario O’Hara is awarded first prize in the Centennial Literary Prize for the sarsuwela. Other winners include Paglayang Minamahal by George de Jesus III, Hibik at Himagsik nina Victoria Laktaw, Atbp by Bienvenido L. Lumbera, and Bayan, Isang Paa na Lamang by Melba Padilla Maggay.

media_caption: Lorraine Natividad and Ric Segreto, in front, and Nannette Moscardon and Joel Lamangan, at the back, in PETA’s Pilipinas Circa 1907, Dulaang Rajah Sulayman, Manila, 1982
text_description: Pilipinas Circa 1907 by Nicanor G. Tiongson, is first staged by PETA under the direction of Soxy Topacio and music direction of Lutgardo Labad, at the Fort Santiago, Manila, demonstrating the best possibilities of sarsuwela aesthetics for modern audiences. (PETA Library and Archives)

media_caption: PETA’s Rak of Aegis, PETA Theater Center, 2014
text_description: Rak of Aegis by Liza Magtoto with music by Aegis, is first staged, under Maribel Legarda, at the PETA Theater Center in Quezon City. It is to date the longest running musical in the Philippines. (Photo by Franco Laurel)

media_caption: Tanghalang Pilipino’s Sa Bunganga ng Pating
text_description: Sa Bunganga ng Pating by Julian Cruz Balmaseda, about usury in the Philippine countryside, is performed at the Manila Grand Opera House. Photo: Tanghalang Pilipino's Sa Bunganga ng Pating, 1996 (Photo from Nicanor G. Tiongson)

media_caption: 2015 staging of Si Bulusan nan Si Agingay
article_title: Theater 1990 Si Bulusan nan Si Agingay
text_description: Si Bulusan nan Si Agingay by Reynaldo “Tootsie” Jamoralin’s (1945 – 2012), a piece on Bikol deities, is first staged by the Sorsogon Community-Based Theater Group. Photo: 2015 staging of Si Bulusan nan Si Agingay (Cynthia Cruz-Paz)

media_caption: Cecilia Benetiz as Potli in DAPAT-Dabaw’s production of Sinalimba, 1987
text_description: Sinalimba, a musical on the issue of ancestral land domain in Mindanao by Fe Remotigue and Don Pagusara, is first staged by DAPAT-Davao in Davao City. (Photo from Cecilia Benetiz)

media_caption: Staging of Tiempos Muertos at the CCP, 1988
text_description: Tiempos Muertos, by Joel L. Arbolario on the life of the sakada in Negros, is first staged in Bacolod City by the Negros Theater League. Photo: Staging of Tiempos Muertos at the CCP, 1988 (Photo from Nicanor G. Tiongson)

media_caption: Dulaang Babaylan's staging of Veronidia in 1973.
text_description: Veronidia, a famous melodrama by Cirio H. Panganiban, is first staged in Bocaue, Bulacan. Photo: Dulaang Babaylan's staging of Veronidia in 1973. (Photo from Nicanor G. Tiongson)

media_caption: Book cover of The World is an Apple and Other Prize Plays by Alberto S. Florentino
article_title: Theater 1955 The World is an Apple
text_description: A pioneering play in the depiction of social realities in English-language Philippine theater, The World Is an Apple, by Alberto S. Florentino, is first staged by the Civic Theater Inc. at the FEU Auditorium in Manila. (Photo from Cultural Publishers)

media_caption: The Manila Grand Opera House on Avenida Rizal, Manila ca 1920s
text_description: The Manila Grand Opera House (formerly Teatro Nacional) opens after being expanded and renovated and welcomes an Italian opera company.

media_caption: The pagdiwata ritual, ca 1983.
media_credit: Photo from Ma’i Collection, Filipinas Heritage Library
text_description: The Palawan and Tagbanwa perform pagdiwata rituals. Photo: The pagdiwata ritual, ca 1983. (Ma’i Collection, Filipinas Heritage Library)

media_caption: An Ifugao ritual in Batad, ca 1980
text_description: Rituals and mimetic dances of the Cordillera groups are performed. Photo: An Ifugao ritual in Batad, ca 1980 (SIL International)

media_caption: Pabasa or Lenten chanting of the narrative of Christ’s passion and death
text_description: The pabasa or chanting of the pasyon continues. (Photo from La Ilustracion Filipina, 1892)

media_caption: Photo: Dulaang UP's staging of Orosman at Zafira in 2010
text_description: Francisco Baltazar’s komedya Orosman at Zafira, written while he is in prison for the Teatro de Tondo, is performed. Photo: Dulaang UP's staging of Orosman at Zafira in 2010 (Virgie Sorita)

media_caption: Dulaang Babaylan's staging of La India Elegante y el Negrito Amante in 1973.
text_description: Francisco Baltazar’s saynete, La India Elegante y el Negrito Amante, is first performed in Udyong (now Orion), Bataan. Photo: Dulaang Babaylan's staging of La India Elegante y el Negrito Amante in 1973. (Nicanor G. Tiongson)

media_caption: Spanish-period Teatro del Principe Alfonso, later Teatro Español, on Arroceros, Manila
text_description: Teatro del Principe Alfonso aka Teatro Español (in photo) and Teatro Nuevo de Arroceros, home of Spanish theater, where Compañia Dramatica de España and an Italian opera company perform, operates. (Photo from CCP)

media_caption: A komedya performance in Bicol in the 1880s
media_credit: Photo from Le Tour du Monde by Jose Montano,1884
text_description: Juan Alvarez Guerra watches a Bikol komedya El Principe Don Grimaldo en el Reino de Sansuena in Legaspi, Albay, further proving that by this time, the komedya are mounted in the local dialects. Photo: A komedya performance in Bicol in the 1880s. (Le Tour du Monde by Jose Montano,1884)

media_caption: Reformist writer Jose Rizal and revolutionary writer Andres Bonifacio
text_description: Andres Bonifacio, possibly with Macario Sakay and Aurelio Tolentino, and friends establish Teatro Porvenir in Tondo.

media_caption: Stage, orchestra, and balconies of the Teatro Zorrilla, Calle Azcaragga (now Claro M. Recto Avenue), Manila, 1911, where operas, sarsuwela, concerts, and other musical events were held in the first decades of the American period
text_description: Teatro Zorrilla, the most elite theater during this time, opens its doors. Its inaugural is the zarzuela El Diablo Mundo by Emilio and Rafael del Val, with music by José Estella. (Photo from Filipinas Heritage Library)

media_caption: Ing Managpe staged by Holy Angel University and Center for Kapampangan Studies (CKS) in 2006.
text_description: The first Kapampangan sarsuwela Ing Managpe by Mariano Proceso Pabalan Byron , with music by Amado Gutierrez David, is first performed at the Teatro Sabina in Bacolor Pampanga. Photo: Ing Managpe staged by Holy Angel University and Center for Kapampangan Studies (CKS) in 2006. (CKS)

media_caption: Lamberto Avellana
text_description: Lamberto V. Avellana (in photo) and Daisy Hontiveros-Avellana lead Barangay Theater Guild, which will continue mounting plays in English written by Filipinos and Western playwrights. (Photo from CCP)

media_caption: Luis Taruc, standing on the right, with members of the Hukbo ng Bayan Laban sa mga Hapon or HUKBALAHAP
text_description: The Hukbalahap conducts flying meetings involving speeches, songs, skits; eventually Juan Feleo leads in establishing the Nueva Ecija Cultural and Dramatic Association (NECDA). (Photo from CCP)

media_caption: Ang Dulang Pilipino, a study on Philippine theater history and playwrights by Julian C. Balmaseda
media_credit: Photo of book cover from Komisyon ng Wikang Filipino and University of the Philippines Press
text_description: Julian Cruz Balmaseda’s Ang Dulang Pilipino, one of the earliest and more comprehensive narratives on the development of Filipino theater from pre-Spanish times to pre-WWII era, is published by the Institute of National Language. (Photo from Komisyon ng Wikang Filipino and University of the Philippines Press)

media_caption: National Artist for Music Antonio J. Molina, awarded in 1973
media_credit: Photo from National Library of the Philippines
text_description: His EminenceEl Gran Cardenal, is staged by the Aquinas Dramatic Guild at the International Fair held in Manila. Photo: Antonio J. Molina (National Library of the Philippines)

media_caption: Philippine-American Life Insurance Company Building in Manila, built in 1961
text_description: Arthur Miller’s Death of a Salesman inaugurates Silliman University’s Portal Players, at the Phil-Am Life Auditorium, Manila. (Photo from CCP)

media_caption: Dulaang UP’s Pagkahaba-haba Man ng Prusisyon sa Simbahan din ang Tuloy, Abelardo Hall, UP Diliman, 1976
text_description: Pagkahaba-haba Man ng Prusisyon sa Simbahan Din ang Tuloy, a translation by Lilia Antonio of William Shakespeare’s Much Ado About Nothing, inaugurates Dulaang Unibersidad ng Pilipinas (Dulaang UP), at the Nicanor Abelardo Hall, UP, under the direction of founder Tony Mabesa. (Photo from Salvador F. Bernal)

media_caption: UP Repertory Company's 1980 staging of Pagsambang Bayan
text_description: Pagsambang Bayan, Bonifacio Ilagan’s reworking of the mass as protest play is performed by the UP Repertory Company under the direction of Behn Cervantes at the UP Diliman. Photo: UP Repertory Company's 1980 staging of Pagsambang Bayan (Photo from Nicanor G. Tiongson)

media_caption: Bodjie Pascua, left, and Joel Lamangan in PETA’s Ang Buhay ni Galileo, Dulaang Rajah Sulayman, Manila, 1981
text_description: Weimar director Fritz Bennewitz directs Ang Buhay ni Galileo, the Filipino translation by Alan Glinoga of Bertolt Brecht’s Galileo Galilei. Production design by Brenda Fajardo exemplifies aesthetics of poverty. Photo from PETA Library and Archives

media_caption: ARTEX Cultural Group reenacting the violent breakup of their strike, 1985
media_credit: Photo from Candy Quimpo and Joi Barrios
text_description: The Artex Cultural Group reenacts the strike they staged the previous year, with workers playing hired goons, to show how the picket line was attacked, resulting in bloodshed. (Photo from Candy Quimpo and Joi Barrios)
